channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Climate change and extreme weather are making retirement even more stressful ‚Äî and expensive
item.description: Extreme weather poses risks to retirement ‚Äî as much as healthcare costs and debt

item.title: An August stocks slump is ‚Äòabsolutely normal‚Äô ‚Äî but strategists urge caution on buying the dip
item.description: Strategists on Friday urged investors to take a cautious approach to a global stock market sell-off.

item.title: UK lenders slash mortgages as Bank of England rate cut brings relief to homeowners
item.description: UK lenders have begun slashing their mortgage rates in a sign that financial pressure on households may be easing after the Bank of England cut interest rates

item.title: Stock market bulls are dangerously close to losing control to the bears
item.description: S&P 500‚Äôs critical support is 5,370.

item.title: Amazon's cloud unit reports 19% revenue growth, topping estimates
item.description: Amazon Web Services grew sales by 19% in the latest quarter, expanding at a faster rate than its parent company.

item.title: Turkey blocks Instagram throughout country amid complaints of censorship of Hamas posts
item.description: The Turkish government did not disclose a reason for the ban nor how long it would be in place.

item.title: Intel to cut 15% of workforce, reports quarterly guidance miss
item.description: Intel will say goodbye to 15,000 employees, cut capital expenditures and forgo a fourth-quarter dividend following weak results and quarterly guidance.

item.title: Nvidia reportedly faces a U.S. DOJ antitrust probe after complaints from rivals
item.description: The U.S. Department of Justice is investigating complaints that Nvidia allegedly abused its market dominance in AI chips, The Information reported.

item.title: Here‚Äôs the dividend-paying stock playbook for Fed rate cuts
item.description: Bad news is bad news again. Time to consider defensive dividend payers

item.title: Ice vests, extra breaks and slushies: Olympians are struggling to keep cool in the Paris heat
item.description: U.S. gymnastics superstar Simone Biles isn't the only Olympian feeling the Paris heat.

item.title: Exxon earnings beat as production in Guyana and Permian sets a record
item.description: ExxonMobil on Friday posted its second highest results for the second quarter in the past decade, helped by record production in Guyana and the Permian Basin.

item.title: Echoes of the dot-com bubble haunt U.S. stocks in 2024. Why investors shouldn‚Äôt worry too much about it.
item.description: Jeremy Grantham‚Äôs GMO said it doesn‚Äôt make sense to draw a parallel between today‚Äôs so-called Magnificent Seven and their equivalents during the boom-and-bust cycle in the late-1990s.

item.title: Apple is spending more on AI, but remains far behind its Silicon Valley peers
item.description: Investors are focused on how much mega-cap tech companies are spending on their AI buildouts. Apple is in a category of its own.

item.title: Intel shares plunge 21% in premarket trading, Nvidia down 3.5% as global chip stocks fall
item.description: Asian stocks including Samsung and TSMC closed lower as European chip firms including ASML also dropped.
